content:
Meeting in 15 minutes!

Add stuff to the agenda here: https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Devtools-kickoff-meeting--AZiMpsO9D8paMrLSl8dQsqoSAg-CGijjZIVoybEvU4Co5Hms
Alright, first up, team updates:
oh also i think @Pascal has an update for after the team updates
yep, but that can wait until the end :)
anyway, for clippy: Mostly normal progress, but we're likely triggering a rust point release for the first time ever (yay? :upside_down: ) , in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/issues/8045
anyone wanna go next?

i'll do rustfmt

  • More minor bug fixes/refactoring
  • Good progress made on a few new features/behaviors, including formatting asm! calls (https://github.com/rust-dev-tools/fmt-rfcs/issues/152) and support for flexibility on line breaking/flattening between chain items
  • 1.58 release
    - minor bug slipped through related to formatting of generated files containing the @generated marker
    - cargo fmt --check now available on all channels

For cargo:

  • 1.59 has strip support and "future incomaptible" reporting for rustc backwards-incompatible changes
  • 1.60 will have new feature syntax
  • Also looking at stabilizing -Ztimings and supporting toml-edit soon.
any additional details on the future incompatible compatibility one?
There's some documentation here: https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/cargo/reference/future-incompat-report.html
Essentially, certain lints can be marked as "this will break soon", and cargo will report it, even if it is inside a dependency.
oh, and this is the first feature under cargo report, right?
yea
rustup and rustdoc? @Daniel Silverstone or @GuillaumeGomez / @jsha ?
I can post the rustdoc one from the doc

- rustdoc
    - A lot of UI improvements made by jsha. We will very likely write a blog post to present them.
    - Cleanup as usual and performance improvements as usual.
i'm excited about the blog post
daniel might not be around today, that's fine
@triagebot next-topic
Unknown command.
oh well forgot the command, @Pascal want to do your update?
yeah, sure! so as y'all might've notices i haven't really had much time for this team in the last year or so
so, with the new year, i'd like to step down
i'd like to make room for new people to join, and maybe also become lead
sad to hear you'll be leaving!
i trust @Manish Goregaokar will continue to do a fantastic job leading the tools team :)
to be clear, i'm not gonna leave the whole community, i'll still be around. just with a team association that matches my activity :)
Thanks for all you've done!
thank you for having me! it's been a blast!
i was going to say i'd enjoyed a great number of your blog posts so glad you'll still be around :grinning:
thanks! there's more coming for sure, maybe even about tools again!
i forgot to mention earlier but i have a few quick AOB type questions whenever we get to the end
then i declare my farewell to be settled, and let's get back to the regular program ;)
i had a few items on the agenda if you're ready?
@Eric Huss go ahead
I just wanted to remind t-devtools members to check their boxes at https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1615, or register a concern otherwise.
I wanted to talk about the meaning of T-dev-tools on the rust-lang/rust repository and what it means.
A lot (most? all?) of these seem unrelated to T-dev-tools, or are covered by T-rustdoc.
So I was wondering what it is intended for?
i hope the lack of responses means that i'm the only one that has no idea
@Eric Huss i think people kinda use it randomly
in general the T- tags mean "needs approval from this team"
but the devtools team is more of a loose federation than a coherent team, with the goal being supporting each other and working together but we don't really ... approve stuff often

being random means it doesn't really have much meaning.

Would anyone object if I at least remove it from the rustdoc issues?
but other teams can and should get their own T- tags
yeah go for it
I can then review the rest and see what makes sense.
There are some for projects that there aren't any active members for.
i think the primary use case is "we want more feedback from wider rust devtools folks"
valid use case, i mean
e.g. if a small team like rustfmt wants to make a big change it kinda makes sense to have a larger approver set
Makes sense.
OK, moving on. I wanted to ask about the status of the issues at https://github.com/rust-dev-tools/dev-tools-team/issues?
Would it make sense to close most of these since they are no longer active or valid?

Manish Goregaokar said:

e.g. if a small team like rustfmt wants to make a big change it kinda makes sense to have a larger approver set

how often do those types of discussions/decisions (for dev tools) happen in the r-l/rust repo though? for example i'd just reach out to you all directly with something vs. opening an issue/PR in the main repo to discuss there
Yea, I don't see them happening on rust-lang/rust much.
Perhaps we should also discuss if this is a good time for this meeting, since few show up and those that do aren't talking?

I'm mostly reading along, since I don't really have much to add usually.

But this meeting is at 10 pm for me, so not really the best time.

Eric Huss said:

Perhaps we should also discuss if this is a good time for this meeting, since few show up and those that do aren't talking?

maybe this question should be teed up again since many weren't able to attend today? fwiw the time works well for me but i've some flexibility on Tuesdays, especially since i find these meetings very valuable
yea. We can also just discuss it async on Zulip or elsewhere.

Eric Huss said:

Would it make sense to close most of these since they are no longer active or valid?

https://github.com/rust-dev-tools/dev-tools-team/issues/36 can _certainly_ be closed
actually any/all rustfmt issues there
i was actually unsure if that was a place you all were really still using, if it made sense to share/ask things there to get it front of everyone
Yeah picking a different time/changing the frequency works
could also make it async, but i think a large benefit of this being sync is that sometimes interesting discussions spawn
but we can have those async too
perhaps a biweekly or monthly @-ping in chat where we ask everyone to drop updates
maybe zulip will make that easier too since the topics/threads will always be grouped vs. discord where they'd likely end up intermingled with other discussion/requests/questions
@Eric Huss where is the RFC for "1.60 will have new feature syntax "? Want to double check how that impacts various tools like cargo-edit.
https://rust-lang.github.io/rfcs/3143-cargo-weak-namespaced-features.html
realize the dev tools repo issue topic is still out there, but i saw RLS in the aob list in dropbox so wanted to note there's some updates that are prob. worth sharing

I just wanted to see if you or Xanewok are still interested in maintaining it? If not, then we need to think about discontinuing it sooner than later. Since it was broken for a long time, and it disrupts beta.
@flip1995 want to speak to the resolution since you basically did all the work on it?
(or making it a subtree)
Yeah, it took some weeks to resolve this, because Xanewok took some PTO and noone else was around to replace them
Especially it depended on Racer (and rustc-ap crates) updates it took even longer
So discontinuing RLS sounds reasonable (ratehr sooner than later)
the good (great?) news though is that the AP crates are out of the dep tree entirely :heart:
Yes AP crates aren't needed anymore
so that's good
Yea, that should help a lot.
We could make a rust (interrnals?) blogpost asking for feedback on how many people still use RLS

there was a thread somewhere about the RLS -> RA transition, but apparently (disclaimer: my recall of the dialog) it's still held up on some administrative tasks and until that's done RLS is still supposed to be the "official" one?
I'm reading this one the side, could someone tell me what AP stand for? :sweat_smile:

xFrednet said:

I'm reading this one the side, could someone tell me what AP stand for? :sweat_smile:

Auto publish

xFrednet said:

I'm reading this one the side, could someone tell me what AP stand for? :sweat_smile:

auto-publish, they are (or at least were) a weekly snapshot of the rustc internal mods published to crates.io for consumption by out-of-tree tools
Ahh, those things. Thanks! :upside_down:

Eric Huss said:

I just wanted to see if you or Xanewok are still interested in maintaining it? If not, then we need to think about discontinuing it sooner than later. Since it was broken for a long time, and it disrupts beta.

i'm around, so don't mind pitching in for the basic keeping-the-lights on stuff if that helps
but i also think the subtree move would probably be ideal so that the breaking chagnes could just be addressed in-tree in real time
Yeah that would help. I basically just needed someone to merge the RLS/Racer PRs.

Caleb Cartwright said:

still held up on some administrative tasks and until that's done RLS is still supposed to be the "official" one?

Yea. I'm of the opinion that there shouldn't be such a high barrier just to link to rust-analyzer from the website, whether it is official or not.

I understand there are still people who prefer RLS, though I'm uncertain why.
Sounds good. I'll keep an eye out, and if things are in a failing state for a while, I'll bring it back up.

Caleb Cartwright said:

but i also think the subtree move would probably be ideal so that the breaking chagnes could just be addressed in-tree in real time

I think with RLS this won't resolve this 100%, since it still depends on Racer, which depends on rustc-dev

flip1995 said:

Caleb Cartwright said:

but i also think the subtree move would probably be ideal so that the breaking chagnes could just be addressed in-tree in real time

I think with RLS this won't resolve this 100%, since it still depends on Racer, which depends on rustc-dev

ahh you are correct, good point
although idr the last time racer broke due to an api change vs. the ap crates just having some e.g. feature that became incompatible on newer nightlies, but yes certainly could happen

Yeah, Racer shouldn't break that often, since it mostly uses pretty "stable" rustc_* crates.

The question is if we want to move RLS in the Rust repo, if the plan is to discontinue it anyway (at some point in the future)

flip1995 said:

Yeah, Racer shouldn't break that often, since it mostly uses pretty "stable" rustc_* crates.

The question is if we want to move RLS in the Rust repo, if the plan is to discontinue it anyway (at some point in the future)

my read is that it's a question of when vs. if with RLS, and i'd fully expect that once RLS goes racer will be fully deprecated too
so is the thinking that if RLS decom is somewhere on the horizon, that it might not even be worth the subtree conversion?
Yes that's what I would say. subtree sync is more complicated than submodule sync. So less people would be able to (quickly) do it, if something breaks.
Yea, I probably wouldn't put in too much effort into that. It doesn't break super often.
I would stay with submodule, if someone is around that can accept Rust update PRs in RLS
makes sense
I think that's all about RLS @triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
i've not really seen the bots in chat before but that's pretty nifty. is there any etiquette on topic transitions? have one minor final item
If no one presses on :working_on_it:, you're good to go with the next topic usually

the last aob item i had was on a somewhat similar note as RLS, there was someone on discord the other day trying to get a hold of someone that supported rust.vim https://github.com/rust-lang/rust.vim/ and seemed they were having trouble. kinda seems like many of the editor plugins are in similar support boats (mostly maintenance without a ton of maintainers)?

i feel like there was a somewhat similar scenario recently with a different plugin (can't remember the specifics) so curious if anyone knew anything about the vim one

Hm seems like there are 2 maintainers, but they don't seem to really review PRs.

(I think I use this plugin, but never had an issue with it, so :shrug: )

yeah and i don't get the sense there's a ton of attention needed, just that the ides-and-editors channel under dev tools in discord gets a fair amount of questions and not uncommon for no one to be able to speak to those definitively
i need to run, seems like meeting has run its course anyway :wave:
@Pascal Oh I'm sad to see you leaving... :'(
(sorry, I was sick so I couldn't attend...)
@Eric Huss re the T-dev-tools label: I agree it should be removed from all the rustdoc issues. I've wondered about it in the past too.
Re RLS deprecation: I think there's an RFC that lays out the plan, including that (IIRC) r-a is supposed to become "official" before RLS is deprecated. I think it's not yet distributed by rustup?
Rust-analyzer is distributed on rustup with the nightly toolchain.
Thanks, I didn't realize that!
